wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the ACCU Platform. Explain its purpose as a comprehensive solution for managing Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCU), including project management, compliance tracking, and carbon credit operations. Document the implementation details, architecture, and relationship to other components. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'ACCU Applications', 'Temporal workflows', and 'CER integration'. Provide practical examples demonstrating common use cases like project creation and ACCU application submission. Document the high-level architecture with frontend, backend, database, and external integrations. Include diagrams from ACCU_Platform_Architecture_Diagram.md to illustrate key concepts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Project Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Project Management module. Thoroughly explain its implementation details, including project lifecycle management, status tracking, methodology integration, and relationship with other modules such as ACCU Applications and Documents. Document the domain model, service layer methods, controller endpoints, and DTOs. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing how projects are created, updated, and queried. Explain integration with Temporal workflows for automated project milestones. Address common issues such as permission errors during project creation and provide solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while offering technical depth on service composition and data validation rules for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architecture Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the ACCU Platform's high-level system architecture. Describe the layered structure including Frontend, API Gateway, Core Services, Data, and External Integration layers as depicted in the Mermaid diagram. Explain the role of each component such as the React/Next.js UI, API Gateway with rate limiting, NestJS business services, and Temporal workflow engine. Document the system boundaries, technology choices, and interaction patterns between layers. Include explanations of scalability, reliability, and compliance features. Provide context on how this architecture supports carbon credit management workflows and regulatory requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: JWT Authentication
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the JWT-based authentication system in the ACCU Platform. Explain the purpose of JWT in securing API endpoints and maintaining user sessions. Document the implementation details of the login flow, token generation, and validation using NestJS Passport and JwtStrategy. Include the structure of the JWT payload containing user ID, email, roles, and tenant ID. Provide practical examples from the codebase showing how the AuthService handles user validation, password hashing with bcrypt, and token signing with JwtService. Explain the integration between AuthController and AuthService for login, registration, and token refresh operations. Address security considerations such as token expiration (15-minute access tokens), secure storage recommendations, and the role of environment variables in configuring JWT secret and expiry times. Include error handling patterns for invalid credentials and expired tokens.

wiki_catalogs.name: User and Role Management Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for User and Role entities. Detail field definitions including id, email, name, password hash, role relationships, and status flags. Explain the many-to-many relationship between users and roles, including join table configuration and cascade behaviors. Document constraints such as unique email indexes and role name validation. Describe data access patterns used in authentication and authorization flows, including how these entities integrate with JWT tokens and RBAC guards. Include examples of common queries for user lookup and role assignment. Address security considerations like password hashing strategy, sensitive data protection, and audit implications of role changes. Provide guidance on extending roles with custom permissions and best practices for role lifecycle management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Workflow Orchestration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on workflow orchestration in the Temporal engine. Explain how the WorkflowOrchestratorService coordinates complex business processes across modules such as ACCU applications, projects, and documents. Document the implementation of workflow definitions using Temporal's TypeScript SDK, including workflow registration, invocation patterns, and state persistence. Provide practical examples from the codebase, such as the ACCU application lifecycle orchestration from draft to issuance. Include details on workflow versioning, child workflows, and signal handling. Illustrate data flow between the orchestrator and activities, and explain error recovery mechanisms. Address integration with the backend API via workflow.controller.ts and scalability considerations for long-running workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Projects API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Projects module endpoints. Document all RESTful routes including GET /projects, POST /projects, GET /projects/:id, PUT /projects/:id, and DELETE /projects/:id. For each endpoint, specify HTTP method, URL pattern, request headers (including Authorization with JWT), query parameters, request body schema using project.dto.ts, and response formats. Include examples of valid and invalid payloads, error responses (400, 401, 403, 404), and success responses with sample JSON. Explain the relationship between projects and other entities like documents, calendar events, and ACCU applications. Document access control via roles.guard.ts and permissions.guard.ts, and provide usage examples from frontend implementation in apps/frontend/src/app/projects/page.tsx. Address common issues such as validation failures, permission denials, and data consistency errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Kubernetes Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Kubernetes configuration of the ACCU Platform. Describe the high-level design of the deployment manifests, including backend and frontend deployments, services, and ingress configurations. Document the pod specifications, container configurations, resource limits, liveness and readiness probes, and security context settings. Explain the use of ConfigMaps and Secrets for environment configuration and sensitive data management. Detail the rolling update strategy with zero downtime, network policies via Ingress with TLS termination, and Prometheus monitoring annotations. Include practical examples from the actual YAML files, such as environment variable injection, volume mounts, and health check endpoints. Address integration with external systems like the database, email, and CER API through environment variables. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common deployment issues like image pull failures, health check timeouts, and secret mounting errors. Discuss scalability considerations based on resource requests and horizontal pod autoscaling potential.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the ACCU Platform. Explain the purpose and role of each technology in the ecosystem. Document the implementation details of the frontend technologies (Next.js 14, React 18, Tailwind CSS, Radix UI), backend technologies (NestJS, TypeORM, PostgreSQL, Redis), workflow engine (Temporal.io), and infrastructure components (Kubernetes, Docker, Prometheus, Grafana). Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase. Provide practical examples of how these technologies work together, such as Next.js App Router with NestJS API endpoints. Document version compatibility and integration patterns between the various technologies.

wiki_catalogs.name: ACCU Applications
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the ACCU Applications module. Explain the complete application lifecycle (Draft → Submitted → Under Review → Approved/Rejected → Issued), including state transitions, validation rules, and integration points with Projects, Documents, and Calendar modules. Document the workflow orchestration via Temporal, including how approval processes and notifications are triggered. Provide code examples of service methods and REST endpoints for submitting and updating applications. Detail the DTO structure and entity relationships. Address common issues such as failed submissions due to missing documentation and provide debugging guidance. Include performance considerations for handling high-volume application batches and compliance with regulatory requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Backend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the NestJS backend application. Detail the modular monolith design with feature-based modules such as AuthModule, ProjectsModule, and AccuModule imported into AppModule. Explain the use of dependency injection, configuration management via ConfigModule, and database integration using TypeOrmModule. Document the role of cross-cutting concerns like rate limiting (ThrottlerModule) and file upload handling (MulterModule). Illustrate how the backend structure enables maintainability and feature isolation while operating as a cohesive system. Include startup process details from main.ts and how global configurations are applied.

wiki_catalogs.name: Refresh Token Flow
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the refresh token mechanism in the ACCU Platform. Explain how refresh tokens enable long-lived sessions while maintaining security through short-lived access tokens. Document the implementation in AuthService.refreshToken method, which verifies the refresh token and issues new access/refresh tokens. Describe the JWT refresh strategy configuration with 7-day expiration and how it's separate from the access token strategy. Include the API endpoint POST /auth/refresh and its request/response schema using RefreshTokenDto and AuthResponseDto. Highlight the security considerations such as not storing refresh tokens server-side in the current implementation and the recommendation to implement token blacklisting in production. Provide examples of client-side token management and error handling when refresh tokens are invalid or expired. Explain the relationship between access tokens and refresh tokens in the authentication workflow.

wiki_catalogs.name: Project and Document Management Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for Project, Document, and FileUpload entities. Explain the hierarchical relationship where projects contain documents, and documents are backed by file uploads. Detail key fields such as project methodology, status, and timeline; document versioning, categorization, and access control; and file metadata including storage location and content type. Document foreign key relationships, cascade delete behaviors, and critical indexes for performance. Describe data validation rules like document naming conventions and project status transitions. Illustrate data access patterns for retrieving project documentation trees and version histories. Include caching strategies for frequently accessed project metadata and performance optimization for large document queries. Address security requirements for document confidentiality and compliance with audit logging.

wiki_catalogs.name: Activity Implementation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this section on activity implementation within the Temporal workflow engine. Explain how individual activities encapsulate discrete units of work such as database operations, email sending, calendar event creation, and notification dispatching. Document the structure of activity functions, their dependency injection via modules like database-activities.module.ts, and their execution context within Temporal workers. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how email-activities.ts integrates with the email.service.ts and how notification-activities interact with the notifications.service.ts. Include information on idempotency, retry policies, timeouts, and error handling strategies. Explain how activities are invoked from workflows and how results are returned. Address performance considerations and best practices for writing reliable, testable activities.

wiki_catalogs.name: ACCU Applications API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed API documentation for the ACCU Applications module. Document endpoints for managing the full application lifecycle: draft creation, submission, review, approval/rejection, and issuance. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, authentication requirements (JWT with specific roles), request/response schemas using accu-application.dto.ts, and status transition rules. Include examples of application submission payloads, validation error responses, and state change workflows. Explain integration points with projects, documents, and temporal workflows. Use examples from README.md to illustrate proper usage patterns. Document how the 90-day rule compliance is enforced through API logic and temporal workflows. Address common issues such as incomplete application data, unauthorized state transitions, and integration failures with external systems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Monitoring & Alerting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the monitoring and alerting setup of the ACCU Platform. Explain the purpose of collecting metrics, generating alerts, and visualizing system health. Document the Prometheus configuration including scrape targets for backend, frontend, PostgreSQL, Redis, and Kubernetes components, along with custom metrics paths and scrape intervals. Detail the alerting rules defined in alertmanager.yml and their integration with Prometheus. Describe the Grafana dashboard 'ACCU Platform Overview' with its key panels for system status, request rate, response time, error rate, database connections, Redis memory usage, CPU/Memory/Disk utilization, and active users. Include examples of PromQL queries used in the dashboard and explain their significance. Provide guidance on setting up alert notifications via Slack, email, or other channels. Address common issues like metric scraping failures, alert fatigue, and dashboard performance optimization. Explain how monitoring integrates with the overall observability strategy and supports compliance requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the ACCU Platform. Describe the high-level design, architectural patterns, and system boundaries. Document component interactions, data flows, and integration patterns as shown in the architecture diagrams. Explain technical decisions, trade-offs, and constraints such as the choice of a modular monolith with feature-based modules. Include infrastructure requirements, scalability considerations, and deployment topology. Provide system context diagrams and component breakdowns from the architecture documentation. Address cross-cutting concerns like security, monitoring, and disaster recovery. Document technology stack, third-party dependencies, and version compatibility. Explain the event-driven architecture with Temporal workflows and the API Gateway pattern with centralized authentication.

wiki_catalogs.name: Document Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Document Management module. Explain document upload, versioning, access control, and workflow integration with Temporal. Document the service layer implementation for secure document handling, including encryption and permission checks. Provide usage examples for uploading, retrieving, and sharing documents via API endpoints. Detail the relationship between documents and other entities like Projects and ACCU Applications. Address common issues such as file size limits, unsupported formats, and permission inheritance. Include performance optimization tips for large document repositories and integration with S3-compatible storage providers. Highlight security best practices for handling sensitive compliance documentation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Frontend Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Next.js frontend application. Describe the App Router structure with server components and React Server Components paradigm. Explain the layout system using layout.tsx and main-layout.tsx, including header and sidebar components. Document the routing structure based on the app directory with pages for ACCU applications, calendar, projects, and settings. Cover state management using React Query and the auth-store, API integration via api-client.ts, and UI component architecture with Tailwind CSS and Radix UI. Highlight how the frontend architecture supports performance, accessibility, and developer experience.

wiki_catalogs.name: Role-Based Access Control
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) implementation in the ACCU Platform. Explain how roles like 'admin', 'user', and others are used to control access to different features and API endpoints. Document the implementation of the @Roles() decorator and RolesGuard that work together to enforce role-based permissions. Show how the Reflector service reads role metadata from route handlers and validates against the user's roles stored in the JWT payload. Provide concrete examples from the codebase showing how controllers use @Roles('admin') to restrict access to sensitive operations. Explain the data flow from user login (where roles are included in JWT) to route protection (where RolesGuard validates permissions). Include details about role assignment and revocation through the AuthService methods assignRole and revokeRole. Address common issues such as role synchronization after permission changes and performance considerations of role lookups.

wiki_catalogs.name: ACCU Application and Audit Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for ACCU and Audit entities. Detail the ACCU application lifecycle states, unit calculations, SER references, and integration with projects. Explain the accu-inventory-item entity for tracking issued units. For audits, document the relationship between Audit, AuditFindings, and AuditLog entries, including severity levels and remediation tracking. Describe foreign key relationships linking ACCU applications to projects and audits to users. Document constraints such as unique application numbers and audit scheduling rules. Explain data access patterns for compliance reporting and audit trail generation. Include performance considerations for querying historical ACCU data and best practices for maintaining data integrity during state transitions. Address regulatory requirements for data retention and immutability of audit logs.

wiki_catalogs.name: State Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for state management in Temporal workflows. Explain how Temporal persists workflow execution state automatically, enabling fault tolerance and long-running processes. Document how state is managed across workflow executions, including use of workflow info, search attributes, and custom state objects stored in the workflow context. Use the ACCU application workflow as a primary example to illustrate state transitions and persistence. Cover how the workflow-monitoring.service.ts exposes state for external tracking and debugging. Include details on querying workflow state, handling state corruption, and implementing state migration strategies. Discuss integration with the temporal.service.ts for state retrieval and the impact of state management on scalability and performance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Documents API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for the Documents module. Document all endpoints for document upload, retrieval, versioning, access control, and deletion. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, request headers (including file upload requirements), request body structure, and response formats. Detail the multipart/form-data upload process and S3-compatible storage integration through file-storage.service.ts. Explain document access control mechanisms using document-security.service.ts and role-based permissions. Include examples of successful uploads, version history retrieval, and access denial scenarios. Document integration with projects, ACCU applications, and audit workflows. Address common issues such as large file uploads, permission errors, version conflicts, and storage provider failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: CI/CD Pipeline
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CI/CD pipeline operations of the ACCU Platform. Thoroughly explain the deployment automation script (deploy.sh), including its prerequisites checking, backup creation, Docker image building and pushing, Kubernetes manifest application, rollout status verification, health checks, and rollback mechanisms. Document the script's environment variables, error handling via trap, and notification system using Slack webhooks. Include concrete examples from the script, such as health check loops, backup restoration procedures, and smoke test integration. Explain the role of other scripts like run-tests.sh for test execution and smoke-tests.sh for post-deployment validation. Describe the integration with CI/CD tools and how the pipeline supports different environments (development, staging, production). Address common issues like deployment timeouts, image build failures, and rollback scenarios. Provide best practices for secure and reliable deployments, including secrets management and zero-downtime strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Modules
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the core modules of the ACCU Platform. Explain the purpose, architecture, and relationship to other components for each major module. Document the implementation details, configuration options, and usage patterns for Project Management, ACCU Applications, Document Management, and Calendar & Deadline Tracking modules. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase. Provide practical examples demonstrating common use cases for each module. Document public interfaces, parameters, and return values. Include diagrams where appropriate to illustrate key concepts and workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Calendar & Deadline Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Calendar & Deadline Tracking module. Explain event creation, deadline reminders, milestone tracking, and integration with project timelines and ACCU application deadlines. Document the service logic for recurring events and automated alerts via Temporal workflows. Provide examples of API usage for fetching user-specific calendars and managing event subscriptions. Detail the data model for CalendarEvent and its relationships with Users and Projects. Address common issues such as timezone mismatches and missed reminders, offering debugging strategies. Include performance considerations for calendar synchronization and scalability with large numbers of concurrent users.

wiki_catalogs.name: Workflow Engine Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Temporal.io workflow engine implementation. Describe how the TemporalModule integrates with the NestJS application and the role of workflow-orchestrator.service.ts in managing business process workflows. Explain the architecture of workflow definitions (accu-application-workflows.ts, calendar-workflows.ts) and activity implementations (calendar-activities.ts, email-activities.ts). Document the event-driven nature of the system where business services trigger workflows for complex operations. Include details on state persistence, fault tolerance, retry mechanisms, and monitoring capabilities. Show how this architecture enables reliable execution of ACCU application lifecycles, document approvals, and compliance workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Permission System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the granular permission system in the ACCU Platform. Explain how permissions provide finer-grained control beyond roles, allowing specific actions like 'project:create', 'document:delete', etc. Document the implementation of PermissionsGuard and its integration with the AuthService.validateUserPermissions method. Describe how permissions are stored as an array in the Role entity and checked against required permissions for each protected endpoint. Provide examples of how controllers would use @Permissions('accu:submit', 'audit:review') decorators (conceptual) to protect routes. Explain the database relationship between roles and permissions, and how users inherit permissions through their assigned roles. Include performance considerations of permission checks and potential optimization strategies like caching. Address security implications of permission management and best practices for assigning least privilege.

wiki_catalogs.name: Calendar and Notification Models
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for CalendarEvent, Notification, and Communication entities. Explain how calendar events track deadlines, milestones, and reminders with start/end times and recurrence patterns. Detail notification types, delivery channels, read status, and user preferences. Describe the communication entity's role in message threading and delivery tracking. Document relationships such as notifications triggered by calendar events or ACCU application status changes. Explain indexing strategies for time-based queries and notification delivery performance. Include data validation rules for event scheduling and message content. Describe data access patterns for generating user dashboards and daily briefings. Address challenges in scaling real-time notification delivery and strategies for handling delivery failures. Provide guidance on implementing the 90-day rule compliance through these models.

wiki_catalogs.name: Error Handling and Retries
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for error handling and retry mechanisms in the Temporal workflow engine. Explain how Temporal provides built-in fault tolerance through activity retries, workflow retries, and exception handling. Document configuration options for retry policies including initial interval, maximum interval, backoff coefficient, and maximum attempts, as implemented in activity invocations. Provide examples from email-activities.ts where transient failures (e.g., network issues) are handled gracefully. Explain how workflow-level errors are caught and processed in accu-application-workflows.ts, including compensation logic and manual intervention points. Cover how the temporal.worker.ts configures global error handling and how failed workflows are monitored and recovered. Include best practices for logging, alerting, and debugging failed executions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Calendar & Events API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed API documentation for the Calendar module. Document endpoints for creating, reading, updating, and deleting calendar events, including deadline tracking and milestone management. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, authentication requirements, request/response schemas using calendar-event.dto.ts, and recurrence rules. Explain integration with projects and ACCU applications for automated deadline creation. Document reminder system implementation and notification triggers. Include examples of event creation with project associations, bulk operations, and conflict detection. Address common issues such as time zone handling, overlapping events, permission errors, and synchronization problems with external calendars.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication & Authorization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the authentication and authorization system of the ACCU Platform. Explain its purpose in securing the application and managing user access. Document the implementation details of the JWT-based authentication with refresh tokens, Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) implementation with custom decorators and guards, and the overall security architecture. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'JWT Authentication', 'Refresh Tokens', 'Role-Based Access Control', and 'Permission System'. Provide practical examples demonstrating common use cases like login flow and role-based access checks. Document public interfaces, parameters, and return values for authentication endpoints. Include diagrams from the security architecture documentation to illustrate key concepts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the Kubernetes-based deployment infrastructure. Detail the deployment specifications for both backend and frontend applications including replicas, resource limits, and health checks. Explain the configuration management using ConfigMaps for environment-specific settings and Secrets for sensitive data. Document the namespace isolation strategy and network policies. Describe the deployment topology including pod distribution, service exposure, and ingress configuration. Cover configuration via docker-compose.yml for local development and its relationship to production Kubernetes manifests. Include scaling strategies, update mechanisms, and environment promotion workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the authentication endpoints in the ACCU Platform. Document the RESTful API endpoints including POST /auth/login, POST /auth/register, POST /auth/refresh, GET /auth/profile, POST /auth/change-password, PUT /auth/profile, POST /auth/logout, and GET /auth/validate. For each endpoint, specify HTTP method, URL pattern, request body schema (LoginDto, RegisterDto, etc.), query parameters, headers (Authorization Bearer token where applicable), and response schemas (AuthResponseDto). Document authentication requirements - which endpoints require JWT authentication and which are public. Include error responses with status codes (401 Unauthorized, 409 Conflict, etc.) and example payloads. Provide curl command examples for each operation and explain the expected workflow for client applications. Address rate limiting considerations and security headers that should be implemented. Document the Swagger/OpenAPI annotations used in the controller for API documentation generation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Monitoring and Debugging
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for monitoring and debugging capabilities of the Temporal workflow engine. Explain how the workflow-monitoring.service.ts provides visibility into active, completed, and failed workflows through metrics and API endpoints. Document how the workflow.controller.ts exposes monitoring endpoints for external consumption and integration with frontend dashboards. Describe the use of Temporal's visibility APIs via temporal.client.ts to query workflow executions, history, and status. Include information on debugging techniques such as workflow replay, event history inspection, and logging strategies. Explain integration with the platform's monitoring stack (Prometheus/Grafana) and how alerts are triggered for stuck or failing workflows. Provide guidance on troubleshooting common issues like timeouts, activity failures, and version mismatches.

wiki_catalogs.name: Users & Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for user management and authentication endpoints. Document public routes: POST /auth/login, POST /auth/register, POST /auth/refresh, and protected routes: GET /users, POST /users, GET /users/:id, PUT /users/:id. For each endpoint, specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas, and authentication mechanisms. Detail JWT token generation, refresh token rotation, and role-based access control. Explain password hashing, session management, and security headers. Include examples of successful authentication flows, token refresh sequences, and error responses for invalid credentials or expired tokens. Document integration with frontend authentication in apps/frontend/src/store/auth-store.ts. Address common issues such as brute force protection, token theft mitigation, and account lockout scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Models & Database Schema
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the ACCU Platform. Detail entity relationships, field definitions, and data types for core entities such as User, Role, Project, Document, AccuApplication, Audit, CalendarEvent, and Notification. Document primary/foreign keys, indexes, and constraints. Explain data validation rules and business rules implemented in the entities. Include database schema diagrams and sample data. Document data access patterns, caching strategies, and performance considerations. Specify data lifecycle, retention policies, and archival rules. Include data migration paths and version management. Address data security, privacy requirements, and access control as implemented in the TypeORM entities.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Layer Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the data persistence layer. Describe the PostgreSQL database as the system of record with TypeORM entities defining the schema. Explain the Redis usage for caching and queuing, and S3-compatible storage for document management. Document the database configuration including connection pooling, SSL settings, and migration strategy. Cover data access patterns, transaction management, and query optimization techniques. Include details on data lifecycle management, backup procedures, and recovery mechanisms. Address how monitoring is implemented for database performance using Prometheus metrics and alerting rules.

wiki_catalogs.name: Notifications API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed API documentation for the Notifications system. Document endpoints for retrieving user notifications, marking notifications as read, and managing notification preferences. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, authentication requirements, request/response schemas, and real-time capabilities. Explain the event-driven architecture using Temporal workflows to trigger notifications for ACCU application status changes, deadline reminders, and audit findings. Include examples of notification payloads, filtering options, and batch operations. Document integration with email.service.ts for delivery and frontend implementation for in-app display. Address common issues such as notification flooding, delivery failures, and preference synchronization across devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the ACCU Platform RESTful APIs. Document HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas, and authentication methods for all endpoints. For each API group (Projects, ACCU Applications, Documents, Calendar, etc.), document the available endpoints with examples. Include authentication requirements using JWT tokens, rate limiting configuration, and error handling strategies. Document common use cases, client implementation guidelines, and performance optimization tips. Address protocol-specific debugging tools and monitoring approaches. Provide migration guides for deprecated features and backwards compatibility notes. Use examples from the actual codebase and README documentation to illustrate proper usage.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the multi-layer security implementation. Detail the network security measures including TLS, rate limiting, and potential WAF integration. Explain the authentication architecture using JWT tokens with refresh tokens and OAuth2 patterns via local.strategy.ts and jwt.strategy.ts. Document the authorization framework with role-based access control implemented through roles.guard.ts and permissions.decorator.ts. Cover data security aspects like encryption at rest, secure secret management, and audit logging. Include compliance considerations for handling sensitive environmental data and user information as defined in security-policy.yml.

wiki_catalogs.name: External Integrations API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive API documentation for external integration endpoints. Document health check routes, CER (Clean Energy Regulator) API integration, and third-party system connectivity. Specify HTTP methods, URL patterns, authentication mechanisms (including API keys and OAuth), request/response schemas, and error handling for external service failures. Detail the CER application submission process, status polling, and response parsing. Explain the retry mechanisms and circuit breaker patterns implemented in external-integration.service.ts. Include examples of successful integration calls, error responses from external systems, and data transformation between internal and external formats. Address common issues such as rate limiting by external APIs, authentication token expiration, and data format incompatibilities.

wiki_catalogs.name: Workflow Engine (Temporal)
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Temporal workflow engine in the ACCU Platform. Explain its purpose in orchestrating complex business processes across different modules. Document the implementation details of workflow orchestration, activity implementation, state management, error handling and retries, and monitoring and debugging capabilities. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'Workflow Orchestration', 'Activity Implementation', and 'State Management'. Provide practical examples demonstrating common use cases like the ACCU application lifecycle workflow. Document public interfaces, parameters, and return values for workflow operations. Include diagrams where appropriate to illustrate key concepts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment & Operations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the deployment and operations of the ACCU Platform. Explain its purpose in ensuring reliable and scalable operation of the platform. Document the implementation details of the Kubernetes configuration, Docker deployment, CI/CD pipeline, monitoring setup with Prometheus and Grafana, and operational runbooks. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'Kubernetes Configuration', 'Scaling Strategy', 'High Availability', and 'Disaster Recovery'. Provide practical examples demonstrating common use cases like deploying to production and troubleshooting common issues. Document configuration options, parameters, and operational procedures. Include diagrams from the deployment architecture documentation to illustrate key concepts.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on getting started with the ACCU Platform. Explain its purpose in helping new developers quickly set up and begin working with the codebase. Document the implementation details of the development environment setup, prerequisites, and initial configuration. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners and technical details for experienced developers. Use terminology consistent with the codebase. Provide practical examples demonstrating common use cases like setting up the development environment, running the application, and executing tests. Document step-by-step instructions for installation, configuration, and basic usage. Include troubleshooting tips for common setup issues and references to additional resources.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Analysis of ACCU Platform

## 1. Project Introduction

The ACCU Platform is a comprehensive system designed for managing Australian Carbon Credit Units (ACCU), providing end-to-end solutions for project management, compliance tracking, and carbon credit operations. The platform serves environmental consultants, project developers, and regulatory compliance officers who require robust tools for managing carbon credit applications, audits, and inventory.

The core goals of the project include establishing a secure, scalable platform for ACCU lifecycle management, implementing robust workflow automation for compliance processes, and providing comprehensive audit trails for regulatory requirements. The platform targets organizations involved in carbon credit generation and trading, with a focus on ensuring compliance with Australian Clean Energy Regulator (CER) requirements.

Sources:
- [README.md](README.md)
- [ACCU_Platform_Architecture_Diagram.md](ACCU_Platform_Architecture_Diagram.md)

## 2. Technical Architecture

The ACCU Platform follows a modern monorepo architecture with a clear separation between frontend, backend, and shared components. The system employs a microservices-inspired modular design within a NestJS backend, with distinct modules for different business domains.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client Browser] --> B[Next.js Frontend]
    B --> C[NestJS Backend API]
    C --> D[Temporal Workflow Engine]
    C --> E[PostgreSQL Database]
    C --> F[Redis Cache]
    C --> G[S3-Compatible Storage]
    D --> E
    D --> F
    D --> G
    C --> H[External Systems]
```

The architecture implements several key design patterns:
- **Layered Architecture**: Clear separation between presentation, business logic, and data access layers
- **Modular Design**: Feature-based modules with well-defined boundaries
- **Workflow Orchestration**: Temporal.io for complex, long-running business processes
- **API Gateway Pattern**: Centralized entry point with authentication and rate limiting

The system leverages Redis for caching and queuing, PostgreSQL as the system of record, and S3-compatible storage for document management. The Temporal workflow engine coordinates complex business processes across multiple services, ensuring reliability and auditability.

Sources:
- [ACCU_Platform_Architecture_Diagram.md](ACCU_Platform_Architecture_Diagram.md)
- [README.md](README.md)

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- Backend: `apps/backend/src/main.ts`
- Frontend: `apps/frontend/src/app/page.tsx`

### Core Modules
- Authentication: `apps/backend/src/modules/auth/auth.module.ts`
- User Management: `apps/backend/src/modules/users/users.module.ts`
- Project Management: `apps/backend/src/modules/projects/projects.module.ts`
- Document Management: `apps/backend/src/modules/documents/documents.module.ts`
- Calendar & Deadlines: `apps/backend/src/modules/calendar/calendar.module.ts`
- ACCU Applications: `apps/backend/src/modules/accu/accu.module.ts`
- Audit Coordination: `apps/backend/src/modules/audits/audits.module.ts`
- Communication: `apps/backend/src/modules/communications/communications.module.ts`
- Notifications: `apps/backend/src/modules/notifications/notifications.module.ts`
- File Storage: `apps/backend/src/modules/file-storage/file-storage.module.ts`
- Email: `apps/backend/src/modules/email/email.module.ts`
- CER Integration: `apps/backend/src/modules/cer/cer.module.ts`
- External Integrations: `apps/backend/src/modules/external/external.module.ts`
- Search: `apps/backend/src/modules/search/search.module.ts`
- Temporal Workflows: `apps/backend/src/modules/temporal/temporal.module.ts`

### Configuration Approach
The platform uses NestJS's ConfigModule for environment management, with configuration loaded from `.env` files and validated at startup. Database configuration is handled through a dedicated `DatabaseConfig` class.

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Environment Variables] --> B[ConfigModule]
    B --> C[DatabaseConfig]
    B --> D[Service Configuration]
    C --> E[TypeORM]
    D --> F[Application Services]
```

### External Dependencies
- Backend: `apps/backend/package.json`
- Frontend: `apps/frontend/package.json`
- Shared: `packages/shared/package.json`

### Integration Points
- CER API: `apps/backend/src/modules/cer/cer.service.ts`
- Email Systems: `apps/backend/src/modules/email/email.service.ts`
- Calendar Systems: `apps/backend/src/modules/calendar/calendar.service.ts`
- IoT Sensors: `apps/backend/src/modules/monitoring/monitoring.service.ts`
- Market Data APIs: `apps/backend/src/modules/accu-inventory/accu-inventory.service.ts`

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[ACCU Platform] --> B[CER API]
    A --> C[Email Systems]
    A --> D[Calendar Systems]
    A --> E[IoT Sensors]
    A --> F[Market Data APIs]
    A --> G[Object Storage]
```

Sources:
- [main.ts](apps/backend/src/main.ts)
- [app.module.ts](apps/backend/src/app.module.ts)
- [package.json](apps/backend/package.json)
- [package.json](apps/frontend/package.json)
- [package.json](packages/shared/package.json)

## 4. Key Features

### Workflow Engine
The platform implements Temporal.io for orchestrating complex business processes such as ACCU application workflows, audit coordination, and document approval processes. This ensures reliability, visibility, and auditability of long-running operations.

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Processing: Start Workflow
    Processing --> Waiting: External Action Required
    Processing --> Failed: Validation Error
    Processing --> Completed: Success
    Waiting --> Processing: Action Completed
    Failed --> Retry: Retry Workflow
    Retry --> Processing
    Completed --> [*]
    Failed --> [*]
```

### Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
The system implements comprehensive RBAC with custom decorators and guards for fine-grained permission control across all endpoints.

### Document Management
A robust document management system supports versioning, access control, and workflow integration for compliance documentation.

### Audit Trail
Comprehensive audit logging is implemented across all entities, capturing changes and providing historical tracking for regulatory compliance.

### Real-time Notifications
A notification system with configurable rules (including the 90-day rule) ensures timely alerts for critical events and deadlines.

### Calendar & Deadline Tracking
Integrated calendar functionality with deadline tracking and automated reminders for compliance milestones.

### CER Integration
Direct integration with the Clean Energy Regulator API for submitting and tracking ACCU applications.

Sources:
- [temporal.module.ts](apps/backend/src/modules/temporal/temporal.module.ts)
- [permissions.guard.ts](apps/backend/src/common/guards/permissions.guard.ts)
- [roles.guard.ts](apps/backend/src/common/guards/roles.guard.ts)
- [documents.module.ts](apps/backend/src/modules/documents/documents.module.ts)
- [audit.entity.ts](apps/backend/src/entities/audit.entity.ts)
- [notifications.module.ts](apps/backend/src/modules/notifications/notifications.module.ts)
- [calendar.module.ts](apps/backend/src/modules/calendar/calendar.module.ts)
- [cer.module.ts](apps/backend/src/modules/cer/cer.module.ts)
</blog>
